description: impure +‎ -ity. From Middle French impurité, from Latin impuritas.

entries.meaning: The condition of being impure; because of contamination, pollution, adulteration or insufficient purification.
examples: Even animals in the Jewish system cause impurity only when they are dead.

entries.meaning: A component or additive that renders something else impure.
examples: The impurities in the iron ore made extraction of the iron very difficult.

entries.meaning: A state of immorality or sin; especially the weakness of the flesh: inchastity.
examples: With his cheating, lying and stealing, he epitomised the impurity of humanity.
